name: Llyn Tegid (Bala Lake)
parking: Paid parking at Bala foreshore and Llangower
hazards: Algal blooms (blue-green algae), deep water, boat traffic
description: Wales' largest natural lake, Llyn Tegid is a stunning glacial ribbon lake roughly 3.7 miles long. It is a hub for watersports, including sailing, kayaking, and swimming. The lake is home to the Gwyniad, a rare fish species trapped here since the last Ice Age. Access is excellent with parking and facilities in Bala and Llangower. While swimming is popular, visitors should be aware of sudden depth changes and the potential for blue-green algae blooms in late summer. The views of the Arenig mountains are spectacular.

name: Llyn Ogwen
parking: Roadside lay-bys on A5 and Ogwen Cottage
hazards: Shallow rocks, cold water, changing weather
description: Llyn Ogwen is a dramatic ribbon lake situated between the Carneddau and Glyderau mountain ranges. Despite its imposing location, it is surprisingly shallow, with a maximum depth of only about 3 meters. This makes it warmer than deeper lakes but also rocky. It is famously associated with the legend of King Arthur's sword Excalibur (Bedivere casting it into the lake). Access is very easy from the A5 road. It offers iconic views of Tryfan and Pen yr Ole Wen.

name: Llyn Idwal
hazards: Cold water, steep approach, strict nature reserve rules
description: Llyn Idwal is a spectacular glacial lake nestled in Cwm Idwal, a National Nature Reserve famous for its rock formations and Darwin's geological studies. Surrounded by the towering cliffs of the Glyderau, the setting is dramatic and moody. Swimming is often debated due to its conservation status, but it remains a bucket-list spot for a quick dip for respectful wild swimmers. The water is crystal clear and cold. Access is via a paved but steep path from Ogwen Cottage.

name: Llyn Padarn
hazards: Boat traffic, cold deep water in centre
description: Llyn Padarn is a designated Bathing Water, making it one of the most popular and safe wild swimming spots in Snowdonia. Located near Llanberis, it is a moraine-dammed lake with easy access points, especially at the lagoons near the slate museum. The lake is used for rowing and kayaking but has plenty of space. It offers stunning views of Snowdon and the historic Dolbadarn Castle. The water quality is regularly monitored and generally excellent.

name: Llyn Gwynant
hazards: Cold spots, kayak traffic
description: Llyn Gwynant is often cited as one of the most beautiful lakes in Wales, famously featuring in the 'Tomb Raider' film. Located in the Nant Gwynant valley, it is easily accessible from the A498. The lake is popular for kayaking and swimming, particularly from the roadside lay-bys or the campsite at the head of the lake. It reflects the surrounding mountains of the Snowdon massif perfectly on calm days. A truly magical spot for a sunrise or sunset swim.

name: Llyn y Fan Fach
hazards: Cold, remote location, steep hike
description: Llyn y Fan Fach is steeped in legend, most notably the 'Lady of the Lake'. Situated high in the Black Mountain range of the Brecon Beacons, it sits beneath a dramatic amphitheatre of cliffs. Reaching it requires a steady uphill hike on a gravel track, making the swim a rewarding finale. The water is deep, cold, and incredibly clear. It is a remote and hauntingly beautiful location, perfect for those seeking solitude and a connection with Welsh folklore.

name: Llyn y Fan Fawr
parking: Tafarn-y-Garreg or Llyn y Fan Fach car park
hazards: Boggy margins, remote, weather changes
description: The larger but slightly less famous neighbour of Llyn y Fan Fach, Llyn y Fan Fawr ('Great Lake of the Peak') is the largest natural lake in South Wales. It sits beneath the steep escarpment of Fan Brycheiniog. The approach is a hike across open moorland which can be boggy. The lake feels wilder and more open than Fan Fach. It is an atmospheric spot for a swim, surrounded by the brooding presence of the Black Mountain peaks.

name: Tal-y-llyn Lake (Llyn Mwyngil)
hazards: Shallow weeds, fishing lines
description: Tal-y-llyn Lake, or Llyn Mwyngil, is a stunning ribbon lake at the foot of Cadair Idris in southern Snowdonia. Formed by a massive ancient landslide blocking the valley, it is relatively shallow and famous for its brown trout. Access is very easy via the B4405 road. The scenery is breathtaking, with the mountain looming directly above. Swimmers should be mindful of anglers and shallow weedy sections, but the location is iconic and serene.

name: Llyn Geirionydd
parking: Car park at lake side (via narrow lane)
hazards: Power boats, water skiers, busy in summer
description: Llyn Geirionydd is unique in Snowdonia as being the only lake where power boats and water skiing are permitted. Consequently, it can be busy and noisy in summer. However, it is a beautiful spot in the Gwydir Forest. There is a car park and toilets. Swimming is possible but requires vigilance due to boat traffic. It is steeped in history, being the reputed home of the bard Taliesin. Best visited early morning or evening for a quieter dip.

name: Llyn Crafnant
parking: Car park near lake or Trefriw
hazards: Fishing lines, cold water
description: Llyn Crafnant is often described as one of the prettiest lakes in Snowdonia, situated in a valley parallel to Geirionydd but much more peaceful. Private boating and swimming are technically restricted in parts due to fishing rights, so discretion is advised (check local signage, often tolerated away from anglers). The scenery is alpine-like with forest meeting the water. A cafe open in summer adds to the appeal. It is a haven for those seeking a quieter experience.

name: Llyn Dinas
hazards: River current at inflow/outflow, shallow rocks
description: Llyn Dinas lies on the floor of the Glaslyn valley near Beddgelert. It is a shallow, accessible lake with the A498 running alongside. It offers easy entry points and is popular for kayaking and canoeing. The lake is surrounded by low hills and has a softer, less rugged feel than the high mountain lakes. It takes its name from the nearby Dinas Emrys hillfort. Good for a relaxed swim with easy parking options.

name: Llynnau Mymbyr
parking: Lay-bys on A4086 near Capel Curig
hazards: Canoe training groups, shallow rocks
description: Llynnau Mymbyr are two interconnected lakes at Capel Curig, famously framing one of the classic views of the Snowdon Horseshoe. The lakes are relatively shallow (max 30ft) and are often used for canoe training by the nearby Plas y Brenin centre. Access is easy from the A4086. Swimming here offers a spectacular backdrop of Moel Siabod and Snowdon. It's an accessible spot for a quick dip with iconic photographic potential.

name: Llyn Eigiau
parking: Remote car park at end of narrow lane from Tal-y-bont
hazards: Remote, broken dam structures, uneven bottom
description: Llyn Eigiau is a large, shallow lake in the Carneddau, famous for the 1925 dam disaster which destroyed the wall (still visible). The lake is now much smaller than its original reservoir size but retains a wild, remote character. Access involves a drive up a long, narrow lane followed by a walk. It feels very secluded. The water is clear, and the broken dam adds a haunting historic element to the swim. Great for escaping the crowds.

name: Llyn Cwellyn
parking: Rhyd Ddu or Snowdon Ranger car parks
hazards: Deep water, fast winds, reservoir restrictions
description: Llyn Cwellyn is a large, deep lake on the western side of Snowdon, flanked by Mynydd Mawr and the Snowdon Ranger path. It is a drinking water reservoir, so check current access rules, but it is also a natural lake enlarged by a dam. It supports a population of Arctic Char. The setting is grand and open. The 'Snowdon Ranger' path starts here. Strong winds can funnel through the valley, making the water choppy. Access is easy from the A4085.

name: Llyn Arenig Fawr
hazards: Cold, deep, remote
description: Llyn Arenig Fawr is a stunning high-altitude lake nestled beneath the crags of Arenig Fawr. It requires an uphill hike to reach, ensuring it is rarely crowded. The water is deep and clear, and the setting is dramatic, often described as one of the finest corrie lakes in Wales. It serves as a reservoir for Bala but retains a very natural feel. A bothy memorial stands nearby. A perfect spot for a wild, high-mountain swim.

name: Llyn Dulyn
parking: Remote car park Llyn Eigiau (long walk)
hazards: Very cold, deep, plane wreckage, remote
description: Llyn Dulyn ('Black Lake') lives up to its name, sitting in a dark, steep-sided corrie in the Carneddau. It is deep (58m) and notoriously cold. The site is poignant due to several aircraft crashes on the cliffs above; wreckage is sometimes visible. It feels incredibly remote and wild. Swimming here is for the hardy and experienced, offering a sombre but majestic atmosphere. Access is a long trek from Llyn Eigiau or the coast.

name: Llyn Bodlyn
hazards: Remote, cold
description: Llyn Bodlyn lies high in the Rhinogydd mountains, supplying water to Barmouth. It is reached via a long walk up the Ysgethin valley, passing the historic Pont Scethin packhorse bridge. The lake is backed by the steep slopes of Diffwys and Y Llethr. It has a wild, rugged character typical of the Rhinogs. A stone causeway once existed but was submerged when the lake was dammed. A remote spot for a determined swimmer.

name: Llyn Llydaw
hazards: Extremely cold (claimed coldest in UK), deep
description: Llyn Llydaw is an iconic glacial lake on the Miners' Track up Snowdon. Famous for its causeway and pipeline, it is heavily visited by walkers but less often swum due to its reputation as the coldest lake in Britain. The setting is magnificent, surrounded by the peaks of the Snowdon Horseshoe. Copper mine ruins line the shore. It is a serious swim for those acclimated to cold water, offering unmatched mountain views.

name: Llyn Cowlyd
hazards: Very deep, steep banks, sudden depth
description: Llyn Cowlyd is the deepest lake in North Wales (70m), a long, dark ribbon of water high in the Carneddau. It is a reservoir held by a high dam and feels bleak and exposed, lacking the softness of lower lakes. It is reached by a hike from Trefriw or Capel Curig. The water is deep and cold. Legends tell of the 'Owl of Cwm Cowlyd'. It is a place for serious swimmers who appreciate a stark, dramatic atmosphere.

name: Llyn Cau
hazards: Cold, deep, steep hike to access
description: Llyn Cau is widely considered one of the most dramatic lakes in Wales, situated in a deep glacial cirque beneath the summit of Cadair Idris. The hike up from Minffordd is steep and strenuous ('the swim you earn'). The lake is almost circular, surrounded by towering cliffs. The water is deep blue and very cold. It is a bucket-list swim for its incredible setting and the sense of achievement in reaching it.
